document.masterDocTitle: The genus Litophyton Forskål, 1775 (Octocorallia: Alcyonacea: Nephtheidae) from Australia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Litophyton Forskål, 1775 (Octocorallia: Alcyonacea: Nephtheidae) from Australia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Holotype NTM C4203 , Queensland , South Great Barrier Reef , Flinders reef, depth
30-35 m
,
21 November 1981
, coll. Z. Dinesen
; two paratypes NTM C4197, Queensland , South Great Barrier Reef; Flinders reef, depth 5-10 m , 26 November 1981 , coll. Z. Dinesen.

Litophyton graafae

holotype NTM C4095; a, abaxial point spindles; b, lateral point spindles; c, tentacle scales; d-e, polyp stalk rods; f, supporting bundle spindles, one partly; g, sclerites of surface layer top of stalk. Scale at b also applies to c-d; scale at g also to a, f.

n. sp. ,

n. sp. ,
holotype NTM C994; a-b, sclerites of surface layer base of stalk; c-d, sclerites of surface layer basal flap; e-f, spindles of interior base of stalk; g, tuberculation of interior base stalk spindle. Scale at f also applies to b; scale at d also to a, e.

FIGURE 18 .
Litophyton projectum
n. sp. ,
holotype NTM C4203; a, abaxial point spindles; b, lateral point spindles; c, tentacle scales; d-e, polyp stalk rods; f-g, supporting bundle spindles, two partly; h-i, spindles of surface layer top of stalk; j-k, sclerites of surface layer base of stalk. Scale at b also applies to c-d, j; scale at a also applies to f, i, k; scale at h also applies to g.

FIGURE 19 .
Litophyton projectum
n. sp. ,
holotype NTM C4203(a-f) and paratype NTM C4197(g-j); a-c, sclerites of surface layer base of stalk; d-e, spindles of interior base of stalk; f, tuberculation of interior base stalk spindle; g, spindles of interior base of stalk; h-i, sclerites of surface layer base of stalk. Scale at a also applies to e, i; scale at b also to h; scale at d also to c, g.

subSubSection.paragraph: Polyps . With irregular arrangement of sclerites in eight points ( Fig. 13d ). Abaxial and lateral point sclerites are spindles with simple tubercles and spiny distal part, largest present abaxially, up to 0.60 mm long ( Fig. 18a ), towards the adaxial points they become smaller ( Fig. 18b ). Several of the point sclerites project beyond the polyp head ( Fig. 13d ). Tentacles with curved scales up to 0.10 mm long ( Fig. 18c ). Adaxial side of the polyp stalk with straight rods up to 0.10 mm long ( Fig. 18 d-e). These rods have a crystalline texture. Supporting bundle composed of one or two spindles up to 2 mm long, with simple tubercles and a spiny tip projecting for a maximum distance of 0.40 mm ( Fig. 18 f-g). Many polyp sclerites have an optically black inner core.
Surface layer top stalk . Spindles up to 1.00 mm long, with simple tubercles ( Fig. 18 h-i).

Surface layer base stalk . Capstans, derivatives of capstans, spindles, and unilaterally spinose spindles, with simple and complex tubercles ( Figs. 18 j-k, 19a-c). The spindles are up to 0.80 mm long.
Interior stalk . Spindles with pointed ends, up to 1.00 mm long ( Fig. 19 d-e), the smaller ones with simple tubercles, the larger ones with more complex tubercles ( Fig. 19f ).

Etymology. The Latin
projectum
, projection, refers to the projecting point spindles of this species.
Distribution . Great Barrier Reef: Flinders reef.

Remarks. This is the only
Litophyton
species with projecting supporting bundle also having projecting point spindles.
